Name: 24-epi-Brassinolide
Description: 24-epi-brassinolide is a 2alpha-hydroxy steroid, a 3alpha-hydroxy steroid, a 22-hydroxy steroid, a 23-hydroxy steroid and a brassinosteroid.

plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the potential of 24-epibrassinolide (EBR), a brassinosteroid analogue, in enhancing phytoremediation of lead (Pb) stress in tall fescue plants. When exposed to Pb, a decrease in shoot and root biomass, as well as chlorophyll and carotenoid productions, was observed in tall fescue. However, foliar application of EBR at different rates mitigated these adverse effects, improving biomass and photosynthetic pigments. The enhanced Pb tolerance was associated with reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulation and increased antioxidative enzyme activities. Notably, EBR application influenced the translocation of Pb within the plant, with a significant improvement in Pb recovery in both shoots and roots. The translocation factor, indicative of Pb movement from roots to shoots, was notably increased with the medium rate of EBR application. This finding suggests that EBR treatment has the potential to enhance the translocation of Pb within tall fescue plants, making it a promising candidate for phytoremediation strategies in Pb-contaminated soils. The study provides valuable insights into the physiological responses of tall fescue to EBR under Pb stress and underscores its potential application in sustainable phytoremediation practices.
plant_translocations.reference: Zhong, W., Xie, C., Hu, D., Pu, S., Xiong, X., Ma, J., … Li, X. (2020). Effect of 24-epibrassinolide on reactive oxygen species and antioxidative defense systems in tall fescue plants under lead stress. Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety, 187, 109831. doi:10.1016/j.ecoenv.2019.109831

method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were sown at a density of 40 g/m2 in pots with topsoil from the 0–20 cm soil layer. Pots were watered daily to maintain soil moisture at 60% of the maximum water holding capacity. The experiment was conducted in a greenhouse with a 16-hour photoperiod, light intensity of 300 μmol photons/m2 s, air temperature ranging from 10 to 22 °C, and an average relative humidity of 60%.
method.Chemical Preparation: A working solution of 24-epibrassinolide was prepared by dissolving solute in ethanol followed by dilution with deionized water (ethanol:water (v/v) = 1:10,000). The experiment consisted of five treatments including the control, Pb (1000 mg/kg Pb), B1 (1000 mg/kg Pb + 0.05 mg/L EBR),B2 (1000 mg/kg Pb + 0.1 mg/L EBR), and B3 (1000 mg/kgPb + 0.2 mg/L EBR)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Plants were treated with Pb (lead acetate) solution at 0 (control) or 1000 mg/kg soil, and with EBR (24-epibrassinolide) solutions at 0, 0.05, 0.1, or 0.2 mg/L, sprayed to the canopy every 7th day for a total of five applications. Control plants were treated with deionized water only. Translocation factor = Pb concentration in shoots/ Pb concentration in roots,  Pb recovery rate (%) = the total amount of Pb extracted in plant/the total amount of Pb applied * 100%.
